Body:
It seems to me (but I may be wrong), that languages tend to evolve towards simplification. Some examples I can think of: loss of declinations in Romance languages or in English, loss of 2nd person specific conjugation in Portuguese (plural in Portugal, singular and plural in Brasil).

One could imagine that such processes continue until a language starts loosing its expressive power. But it seems that languages are not yet all super-simplified. Some complexity is retained to some extent, depending on the language, and even created (for instance, the double negation in French: "Je ne sais" -> "Je ne sais pas" (which may actually be undergoing a simplification: -> "Je sais pas")). What causes languages to sometimes accept new complex features? Aren't the speakers prone to a natural laziness that should oppose to this?

I suppose my question is highly dependent on what "complexity" means.
Title: Why do languages retain or re-create complexity?
